captions.text: *INTRO MUSIC*

Every week for a while now I go to Nick
the editor and say &quot;Have we got any

new review codes worth looking at?&quot; 
and Nick replies &quot;Please stop resting

your cock on my shoulder.&quot; He then 
adds, &quot;Here&#39;s an idea, have you

thought about re-reviewing No Man&#39;s 
Sky? People keep asking you to now it&#39;s

been patched into serviceability like a 
sheep with two robot legs.&quot; And I say

&quot;What? Go back to a game I&#39;ve already 
reviewed? What is this, Eyes Wide

Shut? Maybe while I&#39;m at it I should 
stick a disabled war veteran&#39;s

prosthetic hand up my arse and use 
that to type.&quot; But by all accounts, the

No Man&#39;s Sky of today is a very 
different beast to the partially

developed foetus that plopped out on 
launch day like a mostly dead mouse

from the mouth of an unduly pleased 
with itself cat. &quot;Oh, that was mostly the

publisher&#39;s fault, Yahtz.&quot; Yeah, heard 
that one before. Fuckin&#39; number one

go-to developer excuse, that one, 
right up there with &quot;Well it was working

before Windows updated.&quot; But 
nevertheless I gave it a go, and after it

drew me in for most of the week, I have 
to admit, there has been a significant

unfuckupening. It&#39;s got a third person 
camera now, for one thing, that&#39;s a big

tick. 200% more buttocks flapping 
around at any given moment. No Man&#39;s

Sky by &quot;Hello, games!&quot; is a crafting 
survival exploration space shooter

with an infinite procedural universe 
where you can go from interstellar

flight to waddling about with your 
trousers down looking for the least

classy-looking bush in a meadow with 
seamless transitions all the way, and

obviously that&#39;s so massive in scope it&#39;s 
going to bring down the entire

mouthwash industry. So perhaps a little 
wobbliness was understandable when

we loaded down a newborn baby with 
a rucksack full of expectations and

demanded it take its first step. But let&#39;s 
do this properly. Let&#39;s go over the

points I made in my first review of No 
More Skeroes back in 2016 and see if

they&#39;ve been addressed. Alright, scroll, 
scroll, snarky opening, clumsy analogy,

ah: &quot;The thing about exploration, my 
little pubic louse, is that the appeal lies

in the finding. You can explore a sheet 
of blank printer paper for an

afternoon, but it wouldn&#39;t exactly 
stimulate. There&#39;s nothing to find in No

Man&#39;s Sky you can&#39;t find in about five 
hundred million other places.&quot; Now this

is the eternal sticking point of 
procedurally generated infinity. You

can mash copy paste an infinite 
number of times but you only have a

finite number of assets and different 
arrangements to draw from, so your

infinite universe is going to start 
getting pretty fucking samey after

planet three thousand and two. One of 
the completionist activities available is

surveying planets, scanning all the 
different life forms and uploading the

pictures to teen gossip magazines. 
And it&#39;s hard to feel motivated to do

that when you finish the checklist and 
the game goes &quot;Well that&#39;s one down,

infinity percent to go.&quot; After a while 
every planet&#39;s the same rolling hills

broken up with a squiggly plant every 
few yards and an IKEA flatpacked

alien base every few miles. But here&#39;s 
the thing: there&#39;s no reason to explore

the galaxy, but the game doesn&#39;t seem 
to be asking you to anymore. I played

for like thirty hours and by the end I 
was still in my starting star system.

Because that&#39;s where my base was and 
every crafting resource was available

in it or a neighbouring one. See, 
another thing I said in 2016 was: &quot;The

main question for me was what the hell 
I was supposed to be progressing

towards&quot; and it&#39;s in the area of player 
progress that a lot of. Erm. Progress

has been made. There&#39;s a story 
campaign that you&#39;re doing all this

crafting and planet exploring to 
advance in, sort of like how Subnautica

works but procedural. So every time 
you need to go to a specific character

or facility for the plot the game 
randomly spawns them on or near the

planet you&#39;re already on and says &quot;This 
was here the whole time!&quot; while

coughing and refusing to make eye 
contact. One might reasonably ask at

this point why there needs to be an 
infinite explorable universe at all if you

can get everything done inside one 
conservatively sized cosmic cul-de-sac

as long as the home owner&#39;s 
association&#39;s on board, but I guess it

would be the same without it. I don&#39;t 
particularly want to travel eight trillion

light years to explore a new planet 
with emerald green rocks rather than

chartreuse, but it&#39;s nice to know that I 
could, if I ever get really bored or the

lumpy land mammals that hang out 
near my base start putting up Trump

election flags. It&#39;s like how people 
mainly solo play World of Warcraft but

still want to do it online amid other 
players because there&#39;s no point in

being a cool lone wolf if no one can 
see you do it. And staying on one

planet to build a one to one replica of 
St. Peter&#39;s Basilica is made all the more

special when there&#39;s three thousand 
trillion empty planets you didn&#39;t do it

on. Speaking of online multiplayer, 
that&#39;s another area in which No

Woman No Cry has made up for the 
original version which was about as

communal an experience as picking 
your nose. Now there&#39;s a dimension

hopping space station tardis thing you 
can visit at any time where other

players hang out and you can join 
them on communal missions if you

happen to give a flying antimatter 
powered intergalactic fuck. But it was

nice to see them and look at how many 
of them had gotten hold of ships other

than the default model so I could 
see the quietly in resentment about it.

The communal hub is also where you 
go to buy base blueprints and

progress the path of the plot 
periodically, so it&#39;s the playground

where all the various paths one can 
take intersect, whether you&#39;re one of

the story campaign kids trying to read 
a book, the base building kids putting

together the Legos in the corner or the 
multiplayer kids running around trying

to push each other into the girls&#39; 
toilets. Speaking for myself, I&#39;m a story

campaign kid, and on that front No 
Money No Honey has absolutely

delivered. It now, undeniably, has a 
story campaign. It&#39;s not very GOOD,

but it&#39;s there. I kinda stopped paying 
attention to it around the seventeenth

time it told me to go to a random 
outside toilet on the other side of the

planet and slap the nearest computer 
until some text fell out. But the thing is,

No Hard Feelings was always an easy 
concept to market. That&#39;s why it was

initially more oversold than a Delta 
Airlines flight to Canada after the

midterms. It&#39;s a fully explorable sci-fi 
universe full of life and spectacle.

That&#39;s not like caravanning with the in-
laws, that&#39;s something I WANT to

engage with. All it needed was the 
merest prod of motivation to keep me

interested and that&#39;s what the original 
No Mo Sko couldn&#39;t provide. Now it

can. Even if you stop following the plot 
there&#39;re enough random toys in the

cupboard to find your own motivation. 
You could work towards getting all the

ground vehicle bays and adding 
sloping roofs to all your base buildings

so it functions as a skate park. So after 
all that, amid the populous community

of serviceable crafting survival open 
world games that all want to selfishly

hog your time, No Man&#39;s Sky is now 
officially another one. I think this has

proved the viability of this re-
reviewing lark. Maybe next I could

reload my old Cyberpunk save and see 
if they ever figured out how to make
my trousers spawn back in.
*OUTRO MUSIC*
This video was made possible by...
Closed Captions by @willcblogs
